thread.title: South Africa beat India thanks to Quinton de Kock's century
thread.title_full: South Africa beat India thanks to Quinton de Kock's century

title: South Africa beat India thanks to Quinton de Kock's century
text:
South Africa beat India thanks to Quinton de Kock's century 18 Oct 2015 17:31:55 
comments 
Quinton de Kock's century set up South Africa's 18-run victory over India in the third one-day international as they took a 2-1 lead in the five-match series. 
Opener De Kock made 103 off 118 balls, his fourth ton in seven innings against India, which while Faf du Plessis added 60 to make up for plenty of failures from the South Africa line-up on their way to 270 for seven. 
Morne Morkel then took four wickets as the Proteas were able to restrict India to 252 for six. 
In considerable heat, De Kock showed he has recovered from an ankle suffered earlier this year as he helped power South Africa into a hugely promising position at 205 for two. 
As Du Plessis helped himself to a third-half century in as many matches, they put on 118 for the third wicket - but once the partnership was broken, South Africa managed only 60 runs off the final 10 overs as India's spinners asserted themselves and offered the hosts hope of victory. 
India looked like favourites before they began their reply but South Africa produced a dominant bowling performance, led by Morkel, as they slowed India through the final 20 overs to leave them adrift of their target. 
The hosts were on 207 for three in the 44th over, with their middle order struggling, and Morkel turned up the heat as he claimed two of the next three wickets as India collapsed to 216 for six. 
"It was a very special batting performance," said South Africa captain AB de Villiers. 
"Quinton answered a lot of questions just like how Quinton can do. We struggled between the 37th and 44th over but found our way at the end. 
"To have (David) Miller up front was out of the box thinking from us. We were looking at 250 as a par, the way we fought back with the ball was special." 
"(We) really worked hard this week on mixing it up a bit," added man of the match Morkel. "I'm a rhythm bowler and need things to click to operate. We had a couple of game plans and it is important to execute and we did that. 
"Every time I do well, especially against India, is very special. And it will last with me forever." 
Dhoni, part of the India team which won the second ODI, said: "I thought 270 was a par score, the wicket kept getting slower and slower and the dew didn't help us out. It became a bit two-paced and became difficult to play the big shot." 
Two further ODIs remain, in Chennai and Mumbai, before, in November, the first of four Tests that will conclude South Africa's 72-day tour of the country. Related Sport News
